sentences.sentence: “Well, Watson,” said Holmes when our visitor had left us, “what do you think of it all?”
“I have no idea,” I answered frankly( 坦白地 ). “It is a most mysterious business.”
“As a rule,” said Holmes, “the stranger a thing is, the less mysterious it proves to be.
It is your normal, average crimes which are really puzzling, just as a normal, average face is the most difficult to identify.
But I must act quickly.”
“What are you going to do, then?” I asked.
“To smoke,” he answered.
“It is definitely( 肯定地 ) a three pipe problem – please don’t speak to me for fifty minutes.”
He curled himself up( 蜷缩 ) in his chair, with his thin knees drawn up close to his long, thin nose,
and there he sat with his eyes closed and his black clay pipe sticking out like the beak( 鸟喙 ) of some strange bird.
I had decided that he had dropped asleep, and indeed was feeling sleepy myself,
when he suddenly sprang out of his chair with the gesture of a man who has made up his mind, and put his pipe down.
“Sarasate plays at the St. James’s Hall this afternoon,” he remarked.
“What do you think, Watson? Could your patients spare you for a few hours?”
“I have nothing to do today. My practice is never very absorbing.”
“Then put on your hat and come.
I am going through the City first, and we can have some lunch on the way.
I notice that there is a good deal of German music on the programme, which is rather more to my taste than Italian or French.
It is introspective( 内省的，自省的 ), and I want to introspect( 内省，自省 ). Come along!”
We travelled by the Underground as far as Aldersgate;
and a short walk took us to Coburg Square, the scene of the strange story which we had listened to that morning.
It was a neglected( 被忽视的 ), out-of-the-way place,
where four lines of dirty two-storied( 两层的 ) brick houses looked out into a small fenced area,
where a lawn( 草坪 ) of weedy grass and a few sick-looking bushes were trying to survive in the smoky and polluted air.
Three gold-colored balls and a brown board with “JABEZ WILSON” in white letters, on a corner house,
announced the place where our red-headed client( 客户，委托人 ) carried on his business.
Sherlock Holmes stopped in front of it with his head on one side and looked at it closely, his eyes half-closed but shining brightly.
Then he walked slowly up the street, and then down again to the corner, still looking closely at the houses.
Finally he returned to the pawnbroker’s( 当铺 ),
and, having hit the ground hard with his stick two or three times, he went up to the door and knocked.
It was instantly opened by a bright-looking, clean-shaven young man, who asked him to step in.
“Thank you,” said Holmes, “I only wanted to ask you how you would go from here to the Strand.”
“Third right, fourth left,” answered the assistant quickly, closing the door.
“Smart fellow, that,” observed Holmes as we walked away.
“He is, in my judgment, the fourth smartest man in London, and perhaps the third bravest.
I have known something of him before.”
“Obviously,” said I, “Mr( 先生 ). Wilson’s assistant plays an important part in this mystery of the Red-headed League.
I am sure that you asked your way merely in order that you might see him.”
“Not him.”
“What then?”
“The knees of his trousers.”
“And what did you see?”
“What I expected to see.”
“Why did you hit the pavement( 路面 )?”
“My dear doctor, this is a time for observation, not for talk.
We are spies in an enemy’s country.
We know something of Saxe-Coburg Square.
Let us now explore the parts which lie behind it.”
The road in which we found ourselves as we turned the corner was as great a contrast( 明显的差异 ) to the quiet Saxe-Coburg Square as the front of a picture is to the back.
It was one of the main roads which carry the traffic of the City to the north and west.
The road was blocked with the immense( 巨大的 ) stream of commerce flowing in a double tide( 车流 ) inward and outward,
while the footpaths were black with hurrying pedestrians( 行人 ).
It was difficult to realize as we looked at the line of fine shops and high-class businesses
that directly behind them was the quiet and neglected( 被忽略的 ) square we had just left.
“Let me see,” said Holmes, standing at the corner and glancing along the line,
“I should like to remember the order of the houses here.
It is a hobby of mine to have an exact knowledge of London.
There is Mortimer’s, the tobacconist, the little newspaper shop, the Coburg branch of the City and Suburban Bank, and the Vegetarian Restaurant.
And now, Doctor, we’ve done our work, so it’s time we had some play.
A sandwich and a cup of coffee, and then off to violin-land, where all is sweetness and delicacy and harmony,
and there are no red-headed clients( 客户，委托人 ) to challenge us with their problems.”
My friend was an enthusiastic musician, being himself not only a very capable( 有能力的 ) performer but a composer of great ability.
All the afternoon he sat in the concert hall in the most perfect happiness, gently waving his long, thin fingers in time to the music.
His gently smiling face and his soft, dreamy eyes were as unlike those of Holmes,
the hunter of evil-doers, Holmes the relentless( 坚韧的 ), brilliant, ready-handed detective, as one could possibly imagine.
His unique character had two natures within it,
and his extreme exactness and active intelligence represented, I have often thought,
a reaction against the poetic and contemplative( 沉思的 ) mood( 情绪 ) which occasionally took charge of him.
The swing of his nature took him from extreme laziness to all-consuming energy;
and, as I knew well, he was never so truly formidable( 令人敬畏的 ) as when,
for days on end, he had been lazing in his armchair playing his violin and looking through his rare books.
Then the lust( 强烈欲望 ) of the chase( 追捕 ) would suddenly come upon him,
and his brilliant reasoning power would rise to the level of intuition( 直觉 ),
until those who did not know his methods would look strangely at him, as at a man whose knowledge was not that of other human beings.
When I saw him that afternoon so engrossed( 全神贯注的 ) in the music at St. James’s Hall,
I felt that an evil time might be coming upon those whom he was hunting down.
“You want to go home, no doubt, Doctor,” he said as we came out.
“Yes, I probably should.”
“And I have some business to do which will take some hours.
This business at Coburg Square is serious.”
“Why serious?”
“A major crime is being planned.
I believe we shall be in time to stop it, but today being Saturday rather complicates( 使复杂 ) matters.
I shall want your help to-night.”
“At what time?”
“Ten will be early enough.”
“I shall be at Baker Street( 贝克街，地名 ) at ten.”
“Very well. And Doctor, there may be some little danger, so kindly put your army gun in your pocket.”
He waved his hand, turned on his heel, and disappeared in an instant among the crowd.
I hope that I am no less intelligent than my neighbors,
but I always felt a sense of my own stupidity in my dealings with Sherlock Holmes.
Here I had heard what he had heard, I had seen what he had seen,
and yet from his words it was obvious that he saw clearly not only what had happened but what was about to happen,
while to me the whole business was still confusing and strange.
As I drove home to my house in Kensington I thought over it all,
from the extraordinary story of the red-headed copier of the Encyclopedia( 百科全书 ) down to the visit to Saxe-Coburg Square,
and the ominous( 不吉利的 ) words with which he had parted from me.
What was this night-time expedition( 探险 ), and why did he want me to bring my gun?
Where were we going, and what were we to do?
I had the hint( 暗示 ) from Holmes that this smooth-faced pawnbroker( 当铺老板 )’s assistant was a formidable( 可怕的 ) man—one who might play a deep game.
I tried to puzzle it out( 苦苦思索，弄清楚 ), but gave it up in despair and set the matter aside until night should bring an explanation.

article_info.previous: 顺利工作了一段时间并拿到薪水后的Mr. Wilson突然看到通知说红发会解散了，他的工作也不了了之。他到处都打听不到红发会的消息也联系不上监督他工作的人，于是转向Holmes寻求帮助。
article_info.share_words: His gently smiling face and his soft, dreamy eyes were as unlike those of Holmes, the hunter of evil-doers, Holmes the relentless, brilliant, ready-handed detective, as one could possibly imagine.

question.cn: Holmes对Mr. Wilson当铺前的街道做了什么？
question.en: What did Holmes do to the street before Mr. Wilson’s house?

options.en: He hit the ground with his stick.

options.cn: 他观察了在街道上行走的人。
options.en: He observed the people walking along it.

analysis: 文中提到“Finally he returned to the pawnbroker’s, and, having hit the ground hard with his stick two or three times, he went up to the door and knocked.”所以选A。

question.cn: Holmes敲Mr. Wilson当铺的门时，谁来开的门？
question.en: Who answered the door when Holmes knocked at the door of Mr. Wilson’s house?

analysis: 文中提到“It was instantly opened by a bright-looking, clean-shaven young man, who asked him to step in. . . answered the assistant quickly, closing the door.”可知开门的是Mr. Wilson的助手Vincent Spaulding，所以选B。

question.cn: 两人见面后，福尔摩斯如何评价Vincent Spaulding？
question.en: What did Holmes think of Vincent Spaulding after they met?

analysis: 文中提到Holmes评价说：“Smart fellow. . . He is, in my judgment, the fourth smartest man in London, and perhaps the third bravest.”所以选A。

question.cn: Holmes向Vincent Spaulding问路的真正意图是什么？
question.en: What was the real intention that Sherlock Holmes asked Vincent Spaulding about the way?

options.en: He really wanted to know how to go to the Strand.

options.cn: 他想看Vincent Spaulding头发的颜色。
options.en: He wanted to see the color of Vincent Spaulding's hair.

options.cn: 他想看Vincent Spaulding裤子的膝盖部分。
options.en: He wanted to see the knees of Vincent Spaulding's trousers.

analysis: 文中对话里提到“‘I am sure that you asked your way merely in order that you might see him.’ ‘Not him.’ ‘What then?’ ‘The knees of his trousers.’ ”所以选C。

question.cn: Holmes对音乐的态度是怎样的？
question.en: What was Holmes’s attitude toward music?

analysis: 文中提到“My friend was an enthusiastic musician, being himself not only a very capable performer but a composer of great ability. All the afternoon he sat in the concert hall in the most perfect happiness, gently waving his long, thin fingers in time to the music.”可知福Holmes喜欢音乐，所以选A。

share_title: 100天读完4本英文书，今天是第49天
